stream_context.summary: Kaze, despite feeling very ill, works in Blender on the ‘Return to Yoshi’s Island’ overworld. Parts 1 and 3 are already roughed-out, so this session focuses on sketching Part 2—the connection between them. Most of the time is spent debating how the player should reach the island’s second half after freeing the Yoshis, laying out a mineshaft entrance for Course 3, and placing the Bowser 1 doorway and Mecha-Bowser set piece.

development_findings.summary: Parts 1 and 3 of the overworld are outlined; Kaze begins blocking out Part 2, meaning the entire overworld skeleton is now in progress.
15 of the planned main courses are already finished; remaining work is largely overworld polish and side levels, marking a ‘final-stretch’ phase.

Original idea—pay a Yoshi 100 coins to repair a bridge—was scrapped because it felt out-of-character. New plan: Dory is chained in a central lake; freeing the Yoshis puts one on her back who claims to have ‘freed her with his mighty behind’, allowing Mario to ride Dory across to Part 5.
development_findings.quote: I really hate the Yoshi bridge here… Let’s just have Dory chained to a wall, then after you save the Yoshis a rider appears and you can use her.

development_findings.summary: Course 3 entrance will sit behind breakable crystal rocks in a mineshaft; two Monty Moles will clear the way if Mario tips them 100 coins, establishing that coins can unlock overworld shortcuts.
development_findings.quote: So exhausted from hitting rocks… but for 100 coins I wouldn’t mind speeding up a bit over here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze’s custom physics overhaul removed the classic SM64 invisible walls; he now prefers to leave sequence-break exploits intact instead of adding fake barriers.
development_findings.quote: My engine actually doesn’t have invisible walls anymore… If you can get there, it should just work.

development_findings.summary: Considering a hidden-lake solution (or friendly terrain) because the overworld should ‘feel safe’; doesn’t want lethal drops in this zone.

Planning a series of six sponsor videos (Squarespace) featuring “actor reworks” and possibly a 3-hour ‘every invisible wall’ visualization, generated by code that pans through all collision triangles.
development_findings.quote: That’s the freest video ever… I’ll write the code, then three hours of invisible walls after the ad read.

development_findings.summary: Long-term technical plan: port to PC via Wiseguy’s static re-compilation for 144 FPS. If Nintendo issues a takedown, assets will be swapped to original IP to enable commercial release.
development_findings.quote: I’m half hoping Nintendo shuts me down so I have to exchange all the assets … then I could actually sell it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is ‘incredibly sick’, vomiting multiple times and streaming at reduced speed, attributing the illness to Zeina (‘cooties’).
context_findings.quote: Yesterday I vomited six times before 10 a.m. … I got cooties from Zeina.

context_findings.summary: He distrusts doctors and prefers home care; Zeina made soup and tea.
context_findings.quote: I lost hope in doctors… Zeina made soup and tea.

context_findings.summary: Design philosophy: hates 2D games without analog sticks; dislikes fake difficulty from invisible walls; embraces player freedom and possible exploits.
Financial context: Squarespace deal pays ‘way too much money to pass up’; Kaze is comfortable producing sponsor-driven dev-log content.
context_findings.quote: They want six videos in three months – it’s way too much money to not take it.

context_findings.summary: Legal awareness: received most Nintendo pressure when he wasn’t monetizing; now runs Patreon and YouTube ads but still plans a cautious release window to avoid immediate takedown.

biobak.summary: Active in chat, suggests turning invisible-wall visualization into a sponsor video; Kaze credits him and jokes he’ll become ‘very famous’.
biobak.quote: I’m going to mention you a lot and you’re going to become famous.

biobak.summary: Offers occasional model/layout feedback (e.g., bridge visibility, wooden beam ideas).

zeina.summary: Provided care while Kaze is sick (soup, tea) but also passed the illness to him.
Participates in design brainstorming; her idea of using Yoshis to spawn rafts is rejected because progression must tie directly to freeing Yoshis.

key_stories.title: Sick Day Stream
key_stories.summary: Kaze forces himself to work on the overworld despite severe illness contracted from Zeina. The stream slows down, but viewers see his commitment and the supportive dynamic with his wife.
key_stories.challenge: High fever, vomiting, and lack of sleep threatened to cancel the dev stream.
key_stories.process: He downs tea, lowers music, and openly tells chat he’ll ‘work slow’; Zeina brings soup off-camera.
key_stories.outcome: Progress is still made on Part 2, demonstrating resilience and team support.
key_stories.key_quote: Today I will probably be working a little slow, just because I am so sick.

key_stories.title: Bridge vs. Dory Pivot
key_stories.summary: Originally a Yoshi would repair a bridge for 100 coins to unlock the second overworld zone. Kaze decides this feels wrong and, after chat brainstorming, replaces it with a chained Dory whom the freed Yoshis liberate.
key_stories.challenge: Need a lore-friendly, engaging way to gate progress after Bowser 1.
key_stories.process: Rejects ‘Yoshi repair’ concept, discusses lakes, rafts, and flutter jumps; settles on Dory idea and notes it in design doc.
key_stories.outcome: A more thematic, visually interesting solution that also showcases Yoshis acting as helpers.
key_stories.key_quote: Dory chained to a wall in the lake… After beating Bowser, a Yoshi on her back says he freed her with his mighty behind.

key_stories.title: Squarespace Sponsorship Strategy
key_stories.summary: Kaze secures a lucrative Squarespace deal requiring six videos in three months. Unsure at first, he decides each video will spotlight a separate ‘actor rework’, turning routine coding tasks into paid content.
key_stories.challenge: Delivering six sponsored videos quickly without derailing development.
key_stories.process: Publicly brainstorms content ideas on stream, accepts Biobak’s suggestion to use invisible-wall visualization, and schedules actor-rework showcases.
key_stories.outcome: Generates an income stream while integrating marketing with actual dev work.
key_stories.key_quote: I’m just going to make a video about every single actor rework—such easy content, and it’s way too much money to pass up.

open_questions.context: Stream ends with a written note: ‘Dory chained to a wall… ride her after Yoshis freed’. No technical details provided.
questions: How exactly will the chaining/un-chaining be scripted?
Will Dory get new animations or AI?
Does any team member (e.g., Zeina for animation) need to create custom assets?
What play-testing has been done on the mechanic so far?

open_questions.context: Kaze must deliver six sponsored videos but only vaguely outlined topics.
questions: What is the specific production schedule?
How will he balance dev time vs. editing time?
Will other team members appear in these videos?
Could sponsorship obligations influence design priorities?

open_questions.topic: Potential Asset Swap for Commercial Release
open_questions.context: Kaze ‘half hopes’ Nintendo issues a takedown so he can replace assets and sell the game.
questions: Is there a contingency plan or timeline for asset replacement?
Who would handle original character design, music, and branding?
Would the core gameplay or level design change?
How does the team feel about shifting from a free ROM hack to a commercial product?

open_questions.topic: PC Port via Wiseguy’s Static Recompile
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions Wiseguy’s method as the preferred route for a high-FPS PC version.
questions: Is Wiseguy already involved?
What technical hurdles remain (e.g., controller support, asset formats)?
Will the N64 and PC versions diverge in features?
Who maintains the port long-term?

open_questions.context: Kaze wants to auto-pan through every collision triangle for a three-hour video.
questions: What coding approach will he use to automate camera paths?
Will the tool be released publicly or kept private?
Could this visualization aid level debugging beyond the video itself?
Does he worry about parodying pannenkoek’s work?

open_questions.context: Stream shows only Kaze onscreen; other members contribute via chat or off-stream.
questions: How do Kaze, Biobak, Badub, and Zeina coordinate on daily tasks?
What tools (Discord, Trello, version control) are in use?
How are disagreements resolved, e.g., design pivots like the bridge?
What is each member’s weekly time commitment?
